title: Virgin Australia narrows annual loss
text:
Virgin Australia posts loss of $49m in last financial year by: Robyn Ironside National Aviation Writer From: What are these? Results ... John Borghetti on the tarmac at Sydney Airport with flight attendants Kristy Wheelwright and Raquel Candelario. Source: News Corp Australia 
VIRGIN Australia has managed a $213 million turnaround in the year to June 30, to post an underlying loss of $49 million. 
The figure was revealed in the airline’s fourth quarter results reported to the Australian Securities Exchange today. 
CEO John Borghetti will provide more detail on the full-year results in Sydney next Friday. 
In the June quarter, Virgin Australia posted a $36.9 million underlying loss representing a $46.2 million turnaround on the same period last year. Turnaround ... Virgin Australia CEO John Borghetti will provide detail on the results next week. Picture: Anthony Weate Source: News Corp Australia A statement from the airline said restructuring and transaction costs, as well as “ineffective hedging” incurred costs of $24.9 million in the quarter.
Ineffective hedging refers to the way in which the airline forecast fuel costs, and a failure to capitalise on significant falls in the world oil price. ‘Positive trajectory’ ... CEO John Borghetti with Virgin staff. Source: Supplied Virgin Australia Chief Financial Officer Sankar Narayan said the result represented year on year improvement in the seasonally weaker June quarter.
“We expect to see a continued positive trajectory,” said Mr Narayan. 
“The key highlights in this result have been our performance on non-fuel costs, success in attracting high-yielding market segments and the improved performance of Tigerair Australia.” 
For the quarter, budget carrier Tigerair posted a $9.8 million underlying loss, an improvement of $16 million on the previous corresponding period. Boom time ... Tigerair has had an increase in passenger numbers. Source: Supplied Tigerair also managed to grow passenger numbers in the June quarter by 3.2 per cent whereas Virgin Australia saw domestic and international passengers decrease slightly.
The results are likely to be eclipsed by Qantas’ full-year results due on August 20. 
Analysts are expecting an underlying profit of around $950 million for the Flying Kangaroo and partner Jetstar, representing a $1.6 billion turnaround from FY2014. 
The International Air Transport Association recently advised that airline profit expectations for 2015 had dipped from previous highs, but remained positive. 
“Recent gains in profitability have been driven by strong growth in traffic volumes and falling input costs,” said the IATA report.
